title: 90 years since the Wall Street Crash: will markets be hit as hard again?
text:
Almost $400bn (£309bn) in today’s money, millions of jobs and people's faith in financial institutions: all this was lost in the Wall Street Crash.

On this day 90 years ago, now known as Black Thursday, the American stock market started hurtling down a spiral that saw it lose 90pc of its value, from its 1929 high to when it hit rock bottom in 1932. It took more than a quarter of a century for the market to recover. In Britain, which was caught up in the fall-out, millions were left unemployed and many starved.

But how have subsequent crises compared? Will circumstances ever align to cause another cataclysmic crash? What should investors do if so?

How do more recent crises measure up?
